WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. A. Gibson (née Caley married name Caley)
Address: Princeton
Birthplace: Canada

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1905
Where did you set up housekeeping? Princeton
Where had you been living before that? Canada
For how many people did you prepare meals? 4
How far was it to your nearest store? 5 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Weekly but annual trips
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, flour, dried fruits, tea, soda biscuits, cheese, soda, Baby Rusk, jam, syrup, rice, oatmeal, barley.

To what extent? To sufficient our own needs.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Breakfast** - Porridge - salt pork, bread-butter tea jam or syrup

**Dinner** - Salted cured pork - eggs, potatoes + 2 vegetables milk pudding - (barley, rice, tapioca flour) Bread-butter-tea

**Supper** - Eggs or salmon or codfish or cold pork. Bread for tea cake or B.M. biscuits - potatoes, dried fruit - tea

18. What did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

...1927........ Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Aunt + Uncle, father + self (15) - (Aunt was crippled almost bed-ridden) The menu was varied by having chicken + a plum pudding + mince pies.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.
Small packages - dried fruits off - 10 to a plate

Packaged - 20 oz.

Breakfast - Porridge - oatmeal pack - hard-boiled tea - jam or syrup

Weather - Valley snow pack - apple potatoes - vegetables

Dinner - Turkey, rice, stuffing (bread) Bread rolls - ice

Supper - Egg on toast - noodles in cold pack - Bread pudding

Cake - Baked apples - potatoes - cheese pie - etc.

That night they gave us some, 11:30 p.m. present, and then said

Grandfather, father, mother (father) (father was crippled, about

ten weeks) We came here because of having children,

a place for children, married people.

The next day we went back to almost exactly where we started.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There is now use of fresh fruits & vegetables for salads which is good but the use of too much prepared food is questionable - the use of simple home produced food was a must & so milk puddings etc were more used - we believe there was less digestive trouble. However the use of canned meats & meats fresh from the butcher has lessened the use of the frying pan which is good.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We still rely on our own produce though bread is frequently purchased since '46 as illness & fever in the household made this worse.

Honey was sent from the East in packs

(Boharnos P.)
We still rely on our own produce through breeders.

Money was sent from Mr. Easton in cash.
